results.content: So far it's been a little chaotic. It jumps around a bit things are copied and pasted, ran from the terminal and only a cursory level of explanation is given for why things are done. I would suggest slowing down a bit. Maybe a lesson on the the strategy and tactics. I am a very experienced architect who is searching for a better way to do REST API with Rest Framework. I have experience with the REST API and I am getting lost. I can only imagine what a beginner is going through. I will say, I like that errors are left in the video as they are valuable to the learning process.

results.content:
This is going to sound pretty unforgiving but here goes: I am 40 mins into this course and have YET to learn a thing. The author went on and on about what an api / REST api are which could have been covered in less than 5 mins (if it was necessary information) if he had just prepared a script instead of speaking off the top of his head. The first few lines of code he writes he creates a python virtual environment. He did not explain what that is (probably something worth explaining) or that if you don't have it installed you will get an error. Not a good start.
He then continues his setup at lightening speed to make sure no one can follow what he is doing. I've taken a lot of courses on Udemy and it's not very often I am this frustrated.

results.content:
In general, the course is fine: there is focus on pure Django and this is then compared with REST Framework, which is nice. Also, the explanations and linking to documentation is OK. Presence of unit tests is a must these days and it's great they're here as well.

What could be improved:
- The voice levels could be normalized a bit: it's noticeable when the instructor looks for some notes and increases the distance from microphone.
- Manual testing could be done with e.g. Postman: the way it is done here is very messy: variables get defined here and there, some are commented out, some are not; terminal windows overlap and it's hard to focus on the more important at the moment, etc.

What SHOULD be improved:
- Django version 1.11! There must be an update to 2.x to make it follow current standards.
- No doc strings in written code: that's unacceptable from documentation point of view.

I would recommend this course to newbies (some basic Python and Django experience is required though) if it's taken together with other one, to cover all topics related to Django REST Framework.
results.content_html:
In general, the course is fine: there is focus on pure Django and this is then compared with REST Framework, which is nice. Also, the explanations and linking to documentation is OK. Presence of unit tests is a must these days and it's great they're here as well.

What could be improved:
- The voice levels could be normalized a bit: it's noticeable when the instructor looks for some notes and increases the distance from microphone.
- Manual testing could be done with e.g. Postman: the way it is done here is very messy: variables get defined here and there, some are commented out, some are not; terminal windows overlap and it's hard to focus on the more important at the moment, etc.

What SHOULD be improved:
- Django version 1.11! There must be an update to 2.x to make it follow current standards.
- No doc strings in written code: that's unacceptable from documentation point of view.

I would recommend this course to newbies (some basic Python and Django experience is required though) if it's taken together with other one, to cover all topics related to Django REST Framework.

results.content: This is great course to understand in details about pure Django way to create apis and REST framework way to create apis :) It clarifies different ways we can use to create same api. I would definitely recommend anyone willing to dive a bit deeper into the Django and REST framework's api handling process :) :)
results.content_html: This is great course to understand in details about pure Django way to create apis and REST framework way to create apis :) It clarifies different ways we can use to create same api. I would definitely recommend anyone willing to dive a bit deeper into the Django and REST framework's api handling process :) :)

For all who are interested in the topic a highly recommended course.

results.content: Excellent content and instructor.   I have two small complaints.  First, and this is on Udemy, as learners it should be clear BEFORE purchasing content what versions of frameworks are covered.  This content is quite dated now and the version of Django that it's based on is EOL this month (it covers v1 while v3 is the current. LTS).  The second is that the course sometimes felt less "planned" and more ad hoc.  This is an excellent instructor who is incredibly knowledgeable and is able to pull that off, but a practice run or two would have made it feel more cohesive.

results.content:
So far I'm finding the topic interesting but when compared to other courses I've done this instructor almost seems to be doing things on the fly without a lot of planning.

Whilst typos when coding live on video are bound to happen, often an error is generated and the instructor is fixing it on screen but can't figure out why so just changes the code to make it work.  I would prefer if the instructor actually tested the code first and then made the video or if not that at least work through the original code until it works, then explain what he did wrong.

I've worked through the course up to Video 40 and during this video was completely lost with all the cutting and pasting Justin was doing.

At this point in the course my two key bits of feedback to the instructor would be:

1. Split of all the experimental code into a previous section so we can learnt the do's and don'ts
2. Have "Project" sections where the code can be applied as is intended for the final result so that it can be followed through more easily.

A good example for both of these would be a previous course I did on Django by Jose Portilla:
"Python and Django Full Stack Web Developer Bootcamp"

results.content:
I'm definitely learning the content that I'm promised for the most part but there are times where the instructor doesn't really explain what they're doing and just kind of expects the user to know. Additionally, the way the instructor codes is kind of... messy? Using the same function name multiple times across the same model while having it do different things makes it kind of confusing for the viewer and isn't really how coding would be done in a team setting since it makes it harder to follow exactly what's being done at a glance.

Also, the instructor just talks really fast in general. I normally view other courses at like 1.25 speed but I had to slow this one down to 1x and sometimes even .75x speed despite being a native English speaker. 

Good content, just needs polish on the delivery.

results.content:
The instructeur explains everything very well.
Starts with building the API by itself
and then explains about restframework
So there is no magic and you understand everything

results.content: Thank you very much, Justin. I learnt a lot good stuff.

results.content: A lot of the code in the course is pretty poor and the course's author code re-write a lot of the example code in a more pleasant manner. Also far to much of the course focuses on building out a pure Django rest API which is something which would be better covered in a traditional Django tutorial.
results.content_html: A lot of the code in the course is pretty poor and the course's author code re-write a lot of the example code in a more pleasant manner. Also far to much of the course focuses on building out a pure Django rest API which is something which would be better covered in a traditional Django tutorial.

results.content: Good course. Covers a lot of DRF questions. Thanks

results.content:
This course is fine for me though not self-contained. There is like one or two other courses that are referred to in some instances. Like, if you want to know how the settings file works, you need to take the author's other course(might be free). It would be useful if we are told which section in that course so we can check it out and come back. Even better, if that other course is free and the author owns the videos, why not just include the relevant videos in this course? 

I didn't expect to have to complete 2 other courses before doing this. I was hoping it is self-contained but clearly it is not. Like... Now I need to figure out why a <Model>QuerySet class and <Model>Manager class are pasted in one model, in order to figure that out, I must go and take some other course. That's not cool. I'm worried about that the other course might refer to another course.

For now, I'll just google youtube videos for unexplained sections, I can't be going through another 2 4-hour courses.

results.content:
This is a really good course. I was a bit like "meh" on the section before the Django Restframework one but I was like "let's do it anyway". Good thing I did!!!  Now I understand that knowing the inner workings could help you not be so tied up by the DRF.

Justin is a good instructor, knows his sh**, and explains everything really well.

If you give this course less than 5-stars you are just a cynical ***** who likes trolling good stuff for no reason.
